content:
"Where m is a natural number. "
Including 0 actually. The definitions of a natural number differ regarding 0 being in it.
Well, i found out how to solve this puzzle without the help of Internet, and i'm far to be good at maths or in code. So i guess it's doable, I validate this.

I have changed the statement.
I didn't know that the problems on CG must be such that it would not be necessary to search for additional information on the internet. That assumption causes that some users will not even try to solve certain tasks.
The algorithmic part of this problem is very interesting,. The real question is to know whether there should be a link to the relevant Wikipedia article.

T subsets was to distinguish binary search solutions from those with linear search.
---------------
I have taken into account your comments about 64 bits integer numbers and I have changed test cases to one range and 31 bits integer. 
We still need to generate the right numbers to solve the problem. Brut force with checking every number from given range still shouldn't pass last test.
---------------
What is bad in searching internet to find usefull knowlege?

1. I don't see the point of having T subtests within the test cases. The input should be just two integers a and b.

2. The point of this puzzle is to use internet in order to find the criterion for the feasibility of drawing a regular polygon.

As Boulet said, never use a 64 bits integer since only a few languages can handle them with ease. 
32 is less restrictive but still, some language won't let you get the full range of unsigned integers.
31 is a solid guess and will work with most, while 30 assure you that it's gonna be fine for all.

Otherwise, it's a nice one.
Once again. Please DO NOT USE full 64 bits integers as not all languages can easily manage them on CG

Ruler and compass constructions can be made only with the compass (Mohr-Mascheroni theorem), of course without tracing straight lines.
Eh, brute force won’t work at last.
Ok, then why do you reject?

The first point of this puzzle is to find the criterion then brute-force it.
The second point is to optimize your algorithm in order to solve the last two test cases.
Sorry, I don’t like it now when the optimizing point has disappeared.
Originally the theorem was not given in the statement.

And I don't like it when people offer project-euler-like problem as codingame puzzles.

Having to resort to the internet to find the criterion is the opposite of what one expects from a *puzzle*. And I am sure that you know quite well how insanely hard it is to find this criterion by oneself.

Seriously, the criterion must be explicitly given. And the optimization part (thas is, the pe-like part) should be dropped. People on codingame will enjoy learning some maths properties with an easy puzzle, they will not even try this one in its current statement./


edit: My last sentence also applies to "elliptic curve" (which has an unreadable statement despite nicola's great work to improve it) and to "discrete log" (which is almost impossible to solve without external help).

I disagree.
It’s a good project Euler-like puzzle that won’t have a 100% difficulty in PE. Finding the criterion is mathematical culture, optimizing the code is like in The resistance when your exact script needs improvement.
Discrete log is tough, this one is just fine. Moreover, my Python optimized script is more elegant than my first brute-force one (and I don’t hardcode the Fermat primes :-p).

"It’s a good project Euler-like puzzle that won’t have a 100% difficulty in PE."
-> That is reason enough for a refusal on *CodinGame*.

You want pe-like puzzles with 100% difficulty in PE?
I like this drawer-problem. I don’t know how to explain it in English (problème à tiroirs in French).
The ending of your sentence also means that it won't be 0% difficulty. ;)

Yep.
Maybe something between 20% or 30%. The mathematical part is not tough, finding a right way to optimize is is the interesting part of the puzzle. Think orthogonal as in my sum of divisors problem (which I think you don’t like it either).
Brut force with checking separately every number from given range still shouldn't pass last test.
Yes, I saw.

I realized afterward that my knowledge in mathematics was sufficient to reduce the puzzle to a pure algorithm problem.
Tho, as Stilgart mentionned, most of the users will have to find help elsewhere on the internet, and that's not acceptable for a puzzle, it should be self sufficient.
